reviews.review_text: ☺ Interesting, witty and engaging story. ☺ Lovely, minimalist art style. ☺ Good puzzle platforming.  ☹ Not very challenging gameplay. ☹ A little short.  Thomas Was Alone is a lovely and engaging platformer from start to finish that tells the tale of some plucky AI figuring out their place in the minimalist world they see themselves in. It features some good puzzles based around your team of AI working together to overcome the obstacles before them, each with their own unique ability and personality (which really shines through, despite being simple shapes, thanks to the narration work of Danny Wallace and some good writing).  While a little on the short side, it does manage to stay focused without any padding - although I would have liked the game to have continued for a bit longer with escalating difficulty. The game is quite slow paced with a soothing soundtrack which compliments the minimalist style and produces a rather relaxing experience which is topped off with decent controls that never caused frustration.  While easily recommended for fans of slower paced 2D platformers and those people who like a well written story, the length of the game (and lack of replayabilty) means I'd suggest waiting for a sale.

There is a lot to be said about Thomas Was Alone. It is a cute 2D platformer with simplistic graphics and a stunning use of narration and lighting. Now, the main draw for myself was the narration, and at the end of the experience, the narration was the highlight. It is difficult to describe the connections you end up making with each little character as you progress, all due to the clever use of narration. All the characters have distinct personalities, and all of them end up sticking with the player. I eventually even had a favorite character, and all the while I realized how ridiculous it was that this character happened to be a rectangle with a color assigned to it. Each character has its own gimmick. Whether it is jumping high, being able to swim, fit in tight spaces, etc. These gimmicks create the puzzles that make up the entire game. Without them it would be quite bland. They are always exciting, and easy to understand as they are introduced cleverly. Do I recommend it? Yes I do. For those who want a slow-paced, narrative driven puzzler, this game is the best out there. I loved it. An experience I will remember for years to come.

Thomas Was Alone. Was. But not for long.   This short tale is a heart-warming story of equality, acceptance, sacrifice, and above all, friendship. You may think that the characters in this game are simple rectangles, but they are so much more. Each of them forms a strong character as they strive, as one, to their goal.   They quickly learn to accept their differences; nay, to embrace their differences, using each other’s strengths in order to overcome obstacles and complications which they would never be able to do by themselves, due to their own individual weaknesses and flaws.  Helping them to accomplish their destination, you will be challenged at times, but every time they get one step closer to their collective target will reward you and leave you feeling enthralled.   The game seems simplistic but it flows fluidly and artistically, accompanied with a charming, witty narrative and a beautiful soundtrack. The result: a game that comes together perfectly, filled with emotion and verve.   When I finished the game I found myself wanting to play more of it. Not because it is too short, but because I felt like I had personally connected with each of the characters and I wanted to spend more time getting to know them.  You will laugh, you will cry, but at the finale you will be captivated by this truly magical experience.

Thomas Was Alone is a minimalist 2D platformer, where you play as a group of blocks trying to maneuver through environments to specific exits which are often different for different blocks. The controls are extremely good, and the graphics, while very simple, match with the game's theme and mood.  The story is told via a narrator who recites both what the characters are saying and thinking, much like listening to an audio novel. The approach works well, and serves to anthromorphize characteristics onto what would otherwise be blank slates.  The game is short, and relatively easy - it can be beaten in around 3 hours with nothing additional left to see. That being said, it's a thoroughly enjoyable experience, and I think pretty much anyone would be able to have some fun playing it.

The gameplay is satisfying and never over difficult and the 100 levels take around 4 hours to play through, though without a feeling of repetition due to the constantly evolving abilities of the blocks. Also worth pointing out David Housden's wonderful soundtrack, some of the best game music I've heard in recent years. Despite looking like a low budget indie game, I'd probably say that this is was a strong contender for my 2012 game of the year.

This game has a spectacular story. You play as Thomas, a red rectangle who wonders about what the world is around him. Eventually, he meets other shapes like him, all with different qualities and personalities. Even though these are just shapes on the screen, their personalities, (all narrated by the amazing Danny Wallace), make them feel like real people. Gameplay is simple platforming and all of it relates back to the story. However, that makes it a bit of an easy game, and short. Other that that, there is not many other flaws this game has. It may not be the most revolutionary, but it seems perfectly made, with nothing that seems bad such as glitches, annoying gameplay, or boring sections. It's a cheap, relaxing game to play when you have had enough of the hoopla of many popular titles. Overall, I give this game a 9 out of 10.

The gameplay merely connects the story pieces, and since most of the narration is at the beginning of a level, you don't really want to spend hours trying to figure out how to complete it.  However, for what it does, the gameplay works very well. I used a XBox-360 controller so I can't judge the keyboard controls, but the game did exactly what I told it to do. As you progress through levels, Thomas will eventually no longer be alone, but except for a few levels at the end, no two characters are identical. The narration even assigns them personality; in terms of gameplay they have different sizes, jump lengths and possibly other abilities, so you need to combine them appropiately to get everyone to their designated exit point.  All in all, if you're looking to maximize hours/buck, go elsewhere. If you like to try a simple game with an excellent presentation and execution that -- in my opinion -- doesn't fail at anything it attempts to do, go for it.

Thomas Was Alone is what I believe to be the perfect game to start a non-gamer on, or to represent how good platforming games are these days.  You'll start out as Thomas, a curious red rectangle which is meant to represent a rogue bit of AI. As you progress through the levels, a smooth voice will narrate what Thomas' thoughts and surroundings are, giving a relaxing feel of someone just roaming about, guided by a sense of curiosity. Gradually, you'll meet (and be able to play as) many different characters, all personified with names.  It is the interactions of these shapes, told solely through the narrator, that gives this game heart. Who'd have thought that you could be rapt in the interactions of such simple quadrilateral and monochromaric shapes? They all seem to represent a different mental state; Thomas, the optimistic observer; John, the love-struck grump; and Laura, the cautious outsider, to name a few.  It's also pretty funny at times, with humour that sometimes breaks the fourth wall.  Soundtracks are incredibly important to me, as a great one can ensure you're fully immersed in the game, putting in as much emotional investment as you can. Gladly, Thomas Was Alone perfectly captures an environment that ranges from the serene, to the fast-paced. Apt music at every stage.  For the completionist, there's also additional challenges, mostly involving reaching difficult places, that can squeeze a bit of replayability out of you. Overview: Keep in mind that this is an indie game, so it's not quite designed to bring you the same experience as AAA titles. What I like about indie games in general is that they usually require a small sense of imagination, something that games lack in this era, but that they didn't 10 years ago...  Story: 8/10 The story is what drives this game. The nearer I was toward the end, the more I could feel that sweet Just-One-More-Level Syndrome, just because of how the story is paced. It is also quite ambiguous and philosophical, so I can't be one to judge how well written it is, simply because it should be open for everyone to decide on their own. You play as Thomas and his friends, computer programs that started to pose the most basic questions anyone would ask themselves: 'Why are we here?'. You join in them in their pursuit of knowledge of their surroundings, with a new character appearing every act or so. They each have different personalities and across the levels, they're split up in almost every single combination imaginable between levels. The glue that holds everything together is the narrator, who is expertly voiced in my opinion, simultaneously the only voice heard during the game.  Graphics: 7/10 This is an indie game, it's not supposed to be flashy. Still, while all the water and steam effects are well handled, the game is simple, just as it should be. Still, i think this game could use some more edge curving in the graphics options. Maybe a few more different particle effects.... But, since this is a very artistic game, the one to judge should be the player.  Sound: 8/10 None of the music felt redundant. None at all. For that, the game earns major respect. I can see how much time went into the pacing of this game. The sound effects though are a different matter, I must admit that I was starting to dislike the jump sound for the characters near the end of the game, especially since this is, after all, a platformer, which brings me to the final and most important part of a game:  Gameplay: 7/10 I am a fan of platformers, so I'm not easily tired by them. So as a veteran of the genre, I got to say that this is an extremely easy addition to it. The penalty for dying as any character in a level is simply going back to the last checkpoint, but the game only managed to kill me off in, at most, around 15 levels, levels usually designed from a 'learn from your mistakes' basis. Still, it's also kind of what makes the experience enjoyable, since it's practically a breeze. It lets you focus on the story thanks to that. I guess it just isn't supposed to be a challenging game, like platformers such as Super Meat Boy or Rayman.  Conclusion 7/10 Very enjoyable. If you got this off a Humble Bundle, it is worth the whole bundle. Still, to be completely honest, I think 8 euros on the steam store is just too much. That is my opinion, and it is final because I've finished the game. Still, I've enjoyed every minute in this game (except maybe that one level with those small platforms overthe water), and i recommend it to anyone, since it is unique and doesnt require pro gaming skills.  --Xaelroth

OK, just got 100% on this game and I'll review on five criteria. Gameplay, Plot, Sound, Graphics, and Content.  Gameplay: This game plays like a standard 2D platformer. There are 7 characters you'll be playing as, and they each have different ability. Everyone has a different jump height (The jump in this game is excellent,) and some have special powers such as double jumping or being stuck upside down. However, there are few levels where you play as one character. Almost every level has multiple squares at a time, and you must use the different jumps and powers of each character to get across to the portal which takes you to the next level.  However, these puzzles are cool, but after you figure them out, it takes a long time to physically complete them. The gameplay really suffers from this, as it often has you wishing the squares would move faster. That isn't to say the gameplay isn't good, but this hurts the pace in a lot of ways.  7/10.  Plot: I'll try to make this as spoiler free as possible, but here goes. Thomas is spontaniously generated, and gradually learns how to navigate his environment. He learns how to fall and jump. Eventually, he meets Chris. Chris is smaller, orange and has a weaker jump compared to Thomas. He despises Thomas at first, but they have to work together to get through the place.  Eventually more and more characters are added to the mix, each and every one having tons of backstory, and character. Another thing this game does amazingly is character development. You grow bonds to each character, and the ending was enough to make me cry over these squares jumping from space to space. All because the development of each one is fantastic. Plot is definitely the biggest strength of this game.  10/10  Sound: The whole game has music from David Housden playing in the background. This music is fantastic, but it gets better in the second half of the game. In the first half, the music is rather repetitive. The best part of the whole game though, in my opinion, is the narration. Narrated by Danny Wallace, the narration will make you cry, laugh, and everything in between. It also helps that his voice is amazing.  9/10  Graphics: The graphics are remarkable. Not because they're amazing, but because they push this game to something totally different. While the characters are just squares, and the terrain is black, the background is full of neat colors and always has motion in it. If this game had flat, boring backgrounds, I can safely say I'd like it a lot less. Also, I feel the characters being blocks was the best way to go. As proved by games like Minecraft and Terraria, low graphics are sometimes beautiful.  8/10  Content: This isn't a long game. There are about 100 levels in the main story, but I still completed it in 4 hours. However, there is another, much smaller story arc that tells the tale of a square named Benjamin. This takes place long before the events of the main story.  The achievements don't provide much either. With an even slightly keen eye, you'll get them all in one playthrough like myself. Half of them are even unmissable if you beat the game.  7/10  Overall score: 41/50. This game isn't perfect. The gameplay has some slight annoyances and it isn't very long, but the charm is the prime factor here. The plot is the best I've ever seen in a video game, and the overall feel of the game is GORGEOUS. This game is well worth the 10 dollar price tag, and I recommend it to everybody.

Thomas Was Alone is a charming little platformer indie game. I don't think I've ever felt so many feels for a group of rectangles, before. Thomas is a small, red rectangle AI, and at the beginning of his journey he is, indeed, alone. This soon changes, and his posse grows more and more over the course of the game.  All details of the characters and plot are told by a relaxing British narrator, the kind you may have already encountered in LittleBigPlanet, or The Stanley Parable. Not only is he a good storyteller and pleasant to listen to, he's funny on occasion, as well.  The characterization given to these rectangles is varied, well-defined, and quite interesting. Their story, though not overly complicated at first, really draws you in by the end, with some good twists and turns. For a bunch of colored quadrilaterals, these guys have quite a journey. The best part is that the gameplay always reflects these shifts in plot (and vice versa) in fitting ways. In this way, the puzzles and platforming stay as fresh and compelling as the plot to the very end.  Thomas Was Alone does a lot with a little, and I have to respect it for that.

Thomas Was Alone... First things first, that game... melted my heart. The story was so beautiful, that at one point, I was crying tears of joy. I also will admit the story dragged on a bit towards the end, despite the game being relatively short (I only have 4.1 hours on record (as of typing this at least)), so that's odd. However, when it comes down to it, it was a fun, challenging, heartwarming experience, and I whole-heartedly reccomend it.

While playing through the game, I found the platforming and puzzles adequate; looking back, they seem sufficiently challenging, though at the time they seemed easy. I think that's because most games featuring nothing but rectangles are ludicrously difficult. But that's not really why you should be here.  Thomas was alone is a great example of minimalism and storytelling. It uses the excellent and very British voiceacting and narration to draw you into the events going on. It's almost like a storybook, but read out against a background of something significantly greater going on.  Yeah, I've got niggles about it. At a lot of points the direction the story was going actually kind of aggravated me, but taking a step back the fact that I was invested enough to get aggravated is a point in its favor. At times, the game slowed down a bit, it doesn't seem to be terribly well optimised. And the sheer perilousness of the extra levels, while standard for bonus levels, clashed a bit with the game's overall tone.  That said, Thomas Was Alone is one of those game's that's an experience. An exercise in representation and character with solid core gameplay that is enough to keep it fun and worthy of being a game instead of just an audiobook. It's not the biggest buy you'll find on here, but if it goes on sale I'd say it's totally worth a look.

You use different characters and their abilities to complete puzzles and physical challenges in order to make it to the next level/world. I find that a lot of the time; platformers are very difficult to play on a computer, due to the keyboard being awkward for one's hands. Thomas Was Alone is the quintessential puzzle-platformer of the decade. It's a perfect marriage of gameplay, storytelling and music. It does everything right from its simple and intuitive controls, music that will give you an eargasm, and a compelling narrative that will leave even the coldest heart weeping uncontrollably.  Visually, the game manages to make striking imagery with simple shapes and lighting that will have you grinning like a star-struck child.  The story, combined with Danny Wallace's narration, is superb. Never had I thought I would be so emotionally invested in a group of geometric shapes, but that's just how fantastic and well-crafted Mike Bithell's writing is.  David Housden's music does what music in a visual medium should do: tell the story audibly. It's gorgeous and never misses a beat.  Thomas Was Alone is a charming, challenging, engaging and utterly terrific game that defies convention, showing how you don't have to make a game that's over 12 hours long with state-of-the-art graphics and a convoluted/poorly written plot. There is beauty in simplicity.  It may be only 3 hours, but could just be the best 3 hours you might ever have with a game.

If anyone knows me or has read one of my reviews before, then you probably know that I am a sucker for great storytelling, and it's because of its storytelling that I can confidently claim that Thomas Was Alone is by far my favorite platformer of all time. After saying that I should mention that I don't play many platformers as it is, but still--this game is stellar.   The gameplay is about as basic as it gets. You control Thomas and other diversely shaped blocks you pick up along the way. Each block has their own name, personality and serves a specific function. None of these blocks are expendable. Not only because they're vital to many of the puzzles in the game, but because the narrator names them and tells their story when we meet them. It's mind-boggling to me, how Thomas Was Alone got me attached to a bunch of squares and rectangles. Each shape has their own little story to be told, and the narrator is more than willing to do the talking. It's adorable, really, as you hear the narrator talk of these shapes as if they're people with fleshed out personalities and quirks--exactly how you see them by the end of the game.   The plot of Thomas Was Alone is much more intricate than you may think. This game tells an interesting story that's driven by the characters (the shapes) and their curiosity. By the end of the game you will have grown attached to each of these characters and their mini story arcs. These shapes change, and it's not shown in anything but the dialogue of the narrator, and the steps the player takes to completing the game. There's not much else I can say as the game is so simplistic in nature. All I can do is urge you to Thomas Was Alone if you love a good story or you enjoy a solid platformer. Totally worth the cost.

How can I be so emotionally invested in those simple geometric shapes? That is what I've been asking myself again and again as I played Thomas Was Alone. A big part of that emotion comes from the smart voice-over, fleshing out a plot and character connections that would simply be lost without it. But the other crucial element, and the reason TWA is so effective, is contextual meaning from which it achieves a suspenseful buildup towards a metaphysical resolution.   Scratch that, I'm making the game sound way more pompous than it really is. This is a smart puzzle platformer with great art direction (your eyes will love the contrasts created by light, shadows and colors). It's not taxing, it's actually very relaxing and you'll just want to know what happens next. And you will care for the fates of these little simple shapes. Because we are not solely defined by how we look like, but rather by what we do.  Or something like that. And to be honest, I've written this review to get the Pillar of Community badge. If you like puzzle platformers and snarky British narrators, I cannot recommend this enough. Each shape has a special ability (except Chris, poor Chris): Thomas jumps high; Claire swims; Laura is a trampoline; etc. The level organization does a near-perfect job of introducing the shapes, letting you use them, and familiarizing you with their abilities with the group. The group completes a puzzle when each one reaches their goal: a white portal specific to each shape. The variability with the portal locations and the shape mechanics creates interesting and challenging puzzles.  Did I mention the narrator? Other than quotes shown at the beginning of each chapter that explain a major AI malfunction, he's responsible for progressing the story. And he's wonderful. He shares the shapes' thoughts as they meet each other, judge each other, fall in love, pretend to be superheroes, and everything in between. These shapes have better character development than I've seen in AAA games.  I do have a few quibbles. Alternating between the shapes isn't consistent. Some of the cooperative mechanics between shapes were cumbersome, which is fine for one puzzle. When you require that solution for multiple puzzles, it gets repetitive and frustrating. Such small critiques. Go play the game and enjoy its charming and simple nature.
